channel.title: Gay people allowed to openly serve in US army
channel.description:
The law, known as DADT, which prevented gay people from openly being in the US army has been repealed.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don%27t_Ask,_Don%27t_Tell_Repeal_Act_of_2010
How did America's conservatives justify the blatant discrimination of this law anyway?

item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:14, topic:374554”][quote author=Frell link=topic=470523.msg3440597#msg3440597 date=1293062836]
I think if you’re in the military you should just be in the military.[/quote]

I totally agree. Actually, no, I don’t, but I’ll play along.

The most straight men do in the military is wright letters to their wives or show affection towards a female soldiers, which are usually in Administration and not actively fighting so youll see that rarely.

If by writing letters(oops) showing affection you mean sexually harassing female soldiers then sure, its been what a month?

But seriously, if your justification of such a law that gay people in the military will instantly start disregarding military rules and jump on each others ass the moment it is removed, then your views on such a matter are seriously disturbing. If it’s legal for straight people, it should be legal for gay people. If it’s ILLEGAL for straight people, it should be ILLEGAL for gay people, that’s the whole point of EQUAL rights, no one gets special treatment.

Oh, and if a group of soldiers are freezing to death and a straight soldier won’t huddle with a gay soldier for warmth because he’s too insecure with his sexuality that he’d rather die, then he shouldn’t be serving in the military, end of. The discrimination is already there, removal of the law wont change anything, except maybe give people the rights they deserve.[/quote]

That’s very silly, a lot of gay people work jobs with other gay people and they don’t automatically want to shack up with each other. Take an office job for example two gay guys work in cubicles next to each other, they don’t automatically go off to the store cupboard on their lunch break for a quick shag. Same with if a straight guy and girl are placed next to each other, they don’t go off and shag whenever.[/quote]

en.wikipedia.org

Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010

The Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010 (H.R. 2965, S. 4023) is a landmark United States federal statute enacted in December 2010 that established a process for ending the Don't ask, don't tell (DADT) policy (10 U.S.C. § 654), thus allowing gays, lesbians, and bisexuals to serve openly in the United States Armed Forces. It ended the policy in place since 1993 that allowed them to serve only if they kept their sexual orientation secret and the military did not learn of their sexual orientatio...
